debate.para: Canberra: Meals at Gorman HouseMr. A. M. Blain, M.P.

quote.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: . - I desire to raise a matter relating to certain recent incidents in this city. I would not normally occupy the time of the House at the adjournment by discussing matters affecting the conduct of boarding establishments in Canberra, but an incident has come under my notice-
- I rise to order. I notice that the broadcasting of proceedings has not terminated, although the adjournment debate has commenced.
-Order! The broadcast has ceased.

- I am sure that will be a very great relief to the honorable member. The incident to which I desire to refer is one which affects the liberty of the subject. It is the business of this Parliament not only to consider the liberty of great masses of people, or of people who are themselves powerfully placed, but also to consider the liberty of all citizens, one by one. There is a boarding establishment in this city conducted by the Government named Gorman House. In Gorman House there reside something over 120 female servants of the Crown, most of whom are comparatively lowly paid employees. One of these employees went into the dining-room at Gorman House for dinner on Sunday, the 26th October. By reason of the internal arrangements of this place, the guests line up in a queue and those who are towards the end of the queue therefore get their meals at a substantially later time than the others. When this particular guest, who is a member of the government service, reached her turn, she had occasion to complain to the other girls who were with her that the soup was cold and that the other food was half-cooked. I had thought in my innocence that one of the prerogatives still allowed to us in Australia was to offer some complaint if the food that was produced was not adequate or appropriate! However, the moment she made a critical remark about it to those who were with her, the fact was reported to the cook by a waitress. Before very long, this young woman was interviewed at Gorman House by an official of the union concerned and by a representative of the Department of the Interior. And, what is more, she was told by the union official that, if she entered the diningroom in future, having made this complaint, the staff would go on strike and that no further meals would be served to her!

speech.para: This was on Sunday, the 26th October. We are now ten or eleven days later. It is a dreadful thing to have to record that, by reason of this act of tyranny, this young woman, a perfectly reputable employee of the Government, has been refused the service of any meal in the place in which she lives during the whole of that time. She has had to go out to adjoining cafes or to other places in order to secure her meals. That situation having arisen, a complaint was made in the appropriate quarter. It was taken to the Minister for the Interior (Mr. Johnson) by the house committee of Gorman House. The residents of Gorman House, whose spokesman I am for this purpose, have such a committee, which very properly concerns itself with the well-being of those who reside at the establishment. This committee wrote this letter to the Minister for the Interior -

quote.para: My committee wishes to bring to your attention a state of affairs existing at Gorman House, the women's hostel controlled by your department.
Since last Sunday evening, a guest at the hostel, Miss E. Hines, has been unable to procure any meals because she voiced her opinion on what she thought of the cooking.

speech.para: Miss Hines is, I believe, attached to the Hansard staff. The letter continued -

quote.para: Her remark was relayed back to the cook by a waitress who was not sure of what she heard, and who later tried to get two other guests to make a statement on the matter. The upshot of this was that the staff refused to serve this guest with any meals.

A union representative called on Miss Hines on Sunday afternoon, together with a representative from your department who professed himself unable to do anything in the matter, and stated- that the union had decided that the staff would not serve Miss Hines with any more meals. In view of the fact that a large percentage of residents ' have strongly voiced their opinion on, inter alia, the cooking, this appears to be a straight-out case of victimization. This situation seems to be a flagrant disavowal of all the principles of democracy under which this country is governed, and the mere voicing of an opinion, which was not even heard by the cook in question but obtained by unreliable hearsay, should not condemn a person to go without food. The union representative stated that there had been a lot of complaints from Gorman House and "they just have to stop", and it appears that Miss Hines is being used as a scapegoat.

speech.para: T need not read the rest of the letter, because my time is limited. However, that letter having been sent, the Minister replied to the committee on the 4th November. I do not suggest that he could know all the details of this matter, but at any rate he received the letter from the committee. This is what he wrote -

subdebate.1.para: In reply to your letter of the 29th October, 1 947, I desire to inform you that, at an interview with me this morning, Miss Hines agreed to make an apology to the chef at Gorman House for her statement.

At her request, Miss Hines is being transferred to accommodation at Mulwala House as from Friday afternoon next, 7th November. 1947. [ pause there to -say that it is a very remarkable thing that there should be ministerial sanction of the guest at one of those government establishments having to apologize for a legitimate comment before-

talk.start.para: - Is the right honorable gentleman sure that it was a legitimate comment?
-Order! The Minister may make his explanation afterwards.

- I have not the slightest doubt about its legitimacy. The committee, which, after all, is on the spot and speaks for every one of the 120 inmates, wrote a letter to the Minister in the course of which it indicated that, although Miss Hines alone had had an interview with the Minister and one of his officers, she had not agreed to apologize to the chef in question, and had not done so. The letter proceeds -

quote.para: She is still not being served with meals.

speech.para: That is the fourth item in this list. The committee in its letter then refers to what had been said before and to this particularly outrageous piece of tyranny and the precedent that it created in dealing with these other young women. If the Minister is right and the incident had closed, more or less honorably I presume, by some apology being made to the cook, then one would have expected that Miss Hines would to-night have received her meal. On this very night Miss Hines went into the dining-room for her evening meal. I shall quote the exact words which the waitress spoke to her -

quote.para: I am very sorry, Miss Hines, but our union man will not allow us to serve you. If we do, we will be declared " black " and will not be able to get a job anywhere in Canberra. It is not my fault, I'm sorry.

speech.para: Therefore, Miss Hines left to-night without a meal. I know that this incident is highly amusing to honorable members, opposite.

talk.start.para: - A real joke.

- This is, of course, a joke, but I want to say that as long as this Opposition has a voice to raise, it will defend the liberty of the humblest citizen of this land. It is only a few minutes ago that I heard an honorable member opposite say, " We stand for the little man ". All right. Does the little man include the little woman? Let him stand up to this problem. If we have reached a condition of affairs in this country when in the capital city a union official can condemn a perfectly reputable inhabitant of a government boarding establishment to starve or get out and scratch for food because some complaint has been made, then I should like toknow what has become of liberty. If 10,000 people were involved in an incident of this kind there would he widespread indignation ; but because only one person is concerned in it the incident is dismissed with a lot of childish laughter. It cannot be dismissed with childish laughter. This is an infamous thing which has been done. I call upon the Minister to investigate it and to rectify it, so that there may be proper freedom of speech for the people who live in Canberra and who work for the Government just as the Government claims to guarantee freedom of speech to all other residents of Australia.

. - Honorable members have witnessed the spectacle of the proposed great national leader raising in this Parliament an uninvestigated domestic matter. The right honorable gentleman vouched for the truth of all the statements which he made in the course of his remarks. He had every opportunity to come to my office and ask to see the complete file which contains all the information and negotiations in relation to this incident. He did not do so. Now lie has raised this domestic matter in this House as something of great national importance. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Menzies) claims to be the champion of the down-trodden, the champion of the working-class, the champion of the people. In reply to his remarks, I deny emphatically the allegations which he has levelled against the department. Does the right honorable gentleman stand for the right of freedom to insult? I assume that if he were insulted in this House he would be the first to rise and appeal to the Chair for protection.
- On the contrary, F. never do so.

- No person has the right to insult a cook by saying that he is not fit to cook for pigs. I have had some experience of the control of government establishments. I have given of my best to improve the standard of living of the guests. Recently, I appointed an inspector to visit these establishments continually for the purpose of supervising the food and to ensure that the menus are kept up to a standard of which the guests are entitled. This inspector has now been engaged for six or seven weeks.

speech.para: I want to say to the guests of Gorman House that if the food is in the conditionthat they say it is, I am easily accessible to deputations, but I have never yet received one in regard to complaints about the food at this establishment. I believe from the evidence that I have that the young lady concerned is alleged to have made a most objectionable statement regarding the cook.

talk.start.para: - "Will the Minister come to the point and say whether she is being starved out?
- The Leader of theOpposition does not know anything about this matter. He has never been starved, but I have gone without food.
- Then you should be able to understand this young lady's plight.

- I do understand it.. The complaints made at Gorman House might be justified if all the evidence associated with them were correct; but that is not so. The position at Gorman House is just as good as at any other boarding establishment in this city. Prom an administrative point of view, I realize that it is difficult to please everybody. With regard to the story which the right honorable gentleman told us to-night, the young lady in question came to see me, and I sent for an officer of the department. The young lady undertook to apologize. She did not make that undertaking at my request. After investigating the complaint the trade union concerned decided that it was going to stand by the member of its staff concerned and that members of their staff should not be called names of the kind alleged. In that attitude I entirely agree with them.
- That is nothing less than sheer tyranny - starving a girl !

- If the right honorable gentleman was in the same position he would adopt a similar attitude. He recalls to my mind the old trouble that invariably occurs in shearing sheds. I have had long experience of it. In the first shed the food is all right, the cook is excellent and everybody is happy. In the second shed the " tucker " starts to go off, and the cook is unsatisfactory. By the time they come to the third shed neither the cook, the " tucker ", nor the shed is any good. Of course, the time comes when there is no stew at all.
- This is all very comical except for the lady concerned.
- Finally, as far as the lady herself is concerned-
- Why is she starved ?
- As far as the lady is concerned, she interviewed me in my office yesterday, or the day before--
- Did you give her a meal?

- I should like to give the honorable member for Flinders (Mr. Ryan) a meal of the type provided for a galah. The lady said that she did not want to make any trouble at all in Gorman House, that she had made an indiscreet statement, and that if she had had time to think about it, she would not have made it. She said, " If there is alternative accommodation I am prepared to remove ". She was told that she could go to Mulwala Hostel. I said that that was the .best thing she could do-
- She could starve!

- There is no need for any one to starve in this country to-day, because a Labour government is in office. Times are very different from the days when the right honorable gentleman was in office and 800,000 people were unemployed.
- What a miserable defence of an act of petty tyranny !

- There is no misery attached to it. After making a complete investigation of all the facts associated with the matter - and I am prepared to disclose the file to the Leader of the Opposition if he cares to peruse it-
- I have read its relevant parts.

- If the right honorable gentleman read it, I feel sure that he would adopt the same attitude as I have. The cook resented - and I consider that he is quite justified in his attitude - being called a "pig". I believe that he is justified in adopting the attitude which he did in refusing to accept the insult hurled at him. No member of this Parliament would be prepared to accept an insult of that character.

.- I desire to refer to a matter on which I have strong feelings, and which affects the honorable member for the Northern Territory (Mr. Blain). It is a matter of which I have some personal knowledge, and, therefore, I feel an obligation to refer to it. I am prompted to speak because certain statements have been made which carry inferences'-
- When were th< statements made ?
- I shall come to them.
-The honorable member must come to them now, because, if he is referring to a debate which took place to-day, he is out of order. That is the position. When were the statements made?
- I am not here for interrogation.
- When were the statements made?
- I propose to refer to the imprisonment of the honorable member for the Northern Territory.
- The honorable member must resume his seat.
- May I not refer to the matter of the honorable member for the Northern Territory?
- The question is: " That the House do now adjourn ".
- Mr. Speaker, I rose before you put the question.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

In assessing the significance of these figures it should be remembered that most of the Queensland mines are small and that the New South Wales mines of comparable size have an equally good record for continuity of production.
